br.span: As per Governor Pritzker's Executive Order, School will remain closed through the end of this school year. We will continue to provide updates regarding the closure, cancellations and possible schedule changes.

br.a: Parking Lot Project - Invitation to Bid

p.br: On Friday, April 24 at 9:00AM, a meeting conducted by Dimmick C.C.S.D.#175 will take place via Zoom to discuss plans for providing special education services to students with disabilities who attend private schools and home schools within the district for the 2020-21 school year. If you are a parent of a home-schooled student who has or may be identified with a disability and you reside within the district's boundaries, you are urged to participate. Contact Mr. Linnig, Superintendent via e-mail at rlinnig@dimmick175.com to receive a link to participate or if you have further questions.

span.strong: Welcome to Dimmick Consolidated School District #175 | "Where Children Come First!"
CHECK OUT THE LATEST BLOG ARTICLES:

h2.a: Dimmick Superintendent IV Leads Mentor

div.div: Thursday, April 23, 2020 at 10:06AM | Share Article | Print Article

br.span: Mr. Ryan Linnig has served Dimmick Grade School since 1998 when he was originally hired as a junior high social studies teacher and coach. In 1997, Mr. Linnig completed his Bachelor’s degree in history with teacher certification from Eastern Illinois University. In the years following, he went on to complete his Master’s degree in educational administration at Northern Illinois University, and he received his certificate of advanced study in educational administration from Lewis University. Ryan became superintendent of Dimmick in 2007. During his tenure at Dimmick Grade School, STEM and career exploration have been an integral part of his strategic planning efforts.

Outside of the school setting, Mr. Linnig serves on the North Central Bank board with branches in Hennepin and Ladd. He currently resides in Dimmick, Illinois with his wife Heather, two daughters Payton and Berklee, and his two dogs. He enjoys golfing with friends, woodworking, playing and spending quality time with his family.

h2.a: 4/1/20 - Update from Mr. Linnig

div.div: Wednesday, April 1, 2020 at 08:15PM | Share Article | Print Article

div.p: Dear Parents and Guardians,

Yesterday, Governor Pritzker announced that the shelter at home and mandated school closures would be extended through the end of April. Should there be any changes, we will be sure to keep you informed.

The initial announcement to close schools designated March 13 through March 30 as Act of God days which will not be made up. Beginning March 31, we shifted to “Remote Learning” days which will be counted toward student attendance days therefore it is extremely important that ALL students are engaged in the lessons and learning activities their teachers schedule and or assign.

A copy of the Remote Learning Plan is attached and also posted to the District website: www.dimmick175.com . Please be sure to carefully review the plan so that you understand the expectations throughout these Remote Learning Days. Please note the Daily Attendance Journal Log should be completed each day by either the student or parent to indicate attendance and participation. It should only take a few moments to complete.

The District office and foyer remains open Monday through Thursday from 8am to 12pm and by appointment. We strongly encourage you to call first and maintain social distancing guidelines outlines by the CDC. If you need to get something from your child’s classroom or locker, please call ahead.

We want to reiterate that Spring Break will remain as scheduled on the school calendar (Saturday, April 4 through Monday, April 13). Therefore, remote learning expectations will resume on Tuesday, April 14.

For those who are either participating in the Area Bridge Building Competition or have requested materials to construct them as an enrichment activity, bridges may be dropped off at the school during the office hours indicated above through April 30. If school resumes at that, we will make every attempt to reschedule the event. If the closure should be extended further, we will work to video the busting of each bridge and post the results/video online.

We also want to encourage parents to share any cool videos they have of their children learning from home or engaging in physical activity so that we can put a variety of activities on the District webpage. We also want to encourage students and or parents to complete the daily activity log for P.E. https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1ytvp32x2mAli7BzBeg9faVzoDvhem_V_BDdqxotIrw0/edit.

We hope you and your families remain safe and healthy. Please do not hesitate to reach out if you have any questions or need assistance. In the words of Robert H. Schuller, "Tough times never last, but tough people do." Hang in there! Together we will get through this!

p.a: PLEASE CLICK HERE FOR REMOTE LEARNING PLAN

div.p: Mr. Ryan Linnig

h2.a: IMPORTANT UPDATES REGARDING THE SCHOOL CLOSURE AND E-LEARNING/DISTANCE LEARNING

div.div: Wednesday, March 25, 2020 at 01:52PM | Share Article | Print Article

div.p: Dear Parents and Guardians,

The health and safety of you and your families remains our #1 concern. We hope you are all doing well in these challenging times. I want you to know that we greatly miss working with your children each day, seeing their smiling faces and hearing all of the great stories they have to share. I feel blessed to have the opportunity to work with great kids, parents and this amazing community. We hope and pray that this situation will end as soon as possible so we can get back to normal.
In the meantime, please be sure to remain vigilant in precautionary measures and remain home unless absolutely necessary. We ALL need to do our part to slow the spread of covid19.

Your child’s learning is extremely important to us. Our amazing teachers and staff have been working hard to ensure that all students have access to high quality learning materials, resources and activities. Learning is expected to occur through different means outline below:

ol.li: Learning packets, educational links and instructional resources are posted to the District website dimmick175.com in the top left corner under E-Learning/Distance Learning and are organized by grade level and subject area for specials.
If you need paper copies of packets please email Mr. Linnig and we will make arrangements to get those resources to you.

Teachers will be available and accessibly daily from 8:15am to 2:00pm to email or connect with through various interactive platforms. Be sure to communicate with them and ask any questions you have. They are here to help and assist you in supporting your child’s learning at home.

Many teachers have been scheduling Zoom lessons throughout the day. Please be aware that your child should be joining those lessons, communicating with the teacher and their peers and completing all assigned work.
Work completed and submitted will be graded.

If your child does not have a device to work on assigned schoolwork or to participate in e-learning activities at home, please contact Mrs. Rossman and arrangements will be made to provide you with devices to use during this closure period. This includes all grades K-8.
If you do not have the ability to print from home, contact us and we can make sure that those resources are available in the foyer or that we get them to you through other means.
Zoom, Google Classroom, IXL, Reading A-Z, Raz Kids, Online textbooks, etc. are some of the many resources that are being used.

div.p: We are asking all parents to support your child’s learning by ensuring:

ol.li: Students should have a routine schedule. Consistency is the key to successful student learning.
Students are expected to complete work daily, based on the expectations of each teacher.
All daily work is due by 9 pm the day after it is assigned. Lengthier assignment due dates will be decided by the teacher.
ALL work for the day must be complete in order for the attendance day to be counted.
Students should be prepared with ALL materials and find a quiet, distraction-free place that is conducive to learning when working on any schoolwork.
Students are expected to respond to discussions, interact with one another and ask questions, if they have any.
Grades WILL be taken for work that is submitted and completed.
We strongly encourage students or parents to complete the following log of any learning experiences through this closure period. https://forms.gle/qqHA6z4ZXYKNXMaV7

div.p: Again, we want to stress that the Dimmick teachers, staff and administration are here to assist in any way we can.

As we have indicated many times before one of the best ways you can support your child's learning is by reading to them or having your child read at least 20 minutes every day independently in addition to the opportunities we are sharing. If you are need of books, please be sure to stop out to the school and check out the “Little Library” outside along the entry sidewalk.
Below are several free online learning opportunities you can access giving your child alternative learning opportunities to explore.
I Know It application request form.

a.strong: Easy Hands-On Activities Families Can Do At Home (Teacher Approved!)
18 Best Podcasts for Kids in Elementary, Middle, and High School

div.p: Please keep in mind, that the bridge building kits and instructional resources provided by Illinois Survey and Consultants LLC are still available if you wish to complete a bridge at home. It is a great way for parents and children to spend some high quality, engaged learning time together. There are kits available on a first come first serve basis for any 5th-8th grade students who wish to get one to construct a bridge at home. All bridges constructed may be returned to the school to be tested later. If you are interested in picking up a bridge kit, please contact Mr. Linnig at ryanlinnig@yahoo.com.

At this time, Spring Break will remain as is scheduled on the calendar as we believe it is a strong likelihood that the closure will continue beyond April 7. Events such as the Bridge Building Competition, PTO Field Day, Kindergarten and 8th Grade Graduation, the Dimmick Dash and the Awards Ceremony may be rescheduled once we have direction from ISBE regarding how this closure will impact the school calendar.

This is an amazing community and I know we will get through this. Please remember that we are all in this together and that we all must do everything we possibly can to ensure your child continues to learn and grow during this difficult period. We realize the challenge it can be for students to learn at home however we will continue to be available to support you in any way we can.
We will continue to work hard to find ways to offer learning opportunities for your children and do what is best for them throughout these challenging times.
Please stay safe and healthy!

div.p: Congratulations and best wishes to Dimmick Alumni, Luke Yaklich as he takes over as the UIC men's head basketball coach!

h2.a: Student Learning During the School Closure

div.div: Monday, March 23, 2020 at 09:52AM | Share Article | Print Article

div.p: Dear Parents,

I hope that you and your families are remain healthy and safe during these challenging times. The first confirmed case of the Coronavirus in LaSalle County was announced today, reminding each of us how important it is to remain vigilant in taking precautionary measures. The safety and health of you and your families must remain the top priority. We will continue to update you as new information unfolds.

We want you to know that the Dimmick teachers, staff and administration are here to assist in any way we can. Throughout this week, we have been working to develop a comprehensive e-learning plan to implement in the likelihood that this closure period be extended. We are committed to ensuring that all students have access to high quality learning opportunities. Once that plan is ready, we will be sure to inform you. In the meantime, we strongly encourage parents to establish a consistent routine with your children each day and emphasize the importance of continued learning.

One of the best ways you can support your child's learning is by reading to them or having your child read at least 20 minutes every day independently in addition to the opportunities we are sharing. Below are several online learning opportunities you can access giving your child alternative learning opportunities to explore. We strongly encourage students or parents to complete the following log of any learning experiences through this closure period. https://forms.gle/qqHA6z4ZXYKNXMaV7
Below is a list of links for free alternative online learning opportunities which allow students to choose areas they wish to explore:

ul.li: I Know It application request form.

strong.a: Easy Hands-On Activities Families Can Do At Home (Teacher Approved!)
18 Best Podcasts for Kids in Elementary, Middle, and High School

div.p: In addition, we had planned to hold our annual bridge building competition on March 27 which we hope to reschedule if possible. Illinois Survey and Consultants LLC is our sponsor for the competition and have provided all of the materials for the areas schools and we are grateful for their support. There are kits available on a first come first serve basis for any 5th-8th grade students who wish to get one to construct a bridge at home. This would be a great opportunity for parent to work with their children on a hands-on project at home. All bridges constructed may be returned to the school to be tested later. If you are interested in picking up a bridge kit, please contact Mr. Linnig at ryanlinnig@yahoo.com.

Guidance from the Illinois State Board of Education has been changing throughout this closure period and the work students complete can now be graded to reward student effort and boost current grades.

I want you to know that our number one priority is the safety and health of each and every one of our students, staff, parents and members of the Dimmick Community. We will continue to work hard to find ways to offer learning opportunities for your children and do what is best for them throughout these challenging times.
Please stay safe and healthy!

Mr. Ryan Linnig
Superintendent

h2.a: Mark Your Calendars! Academic Fair & Band Concert

div.div: Thursday, March 12, 2020 at 02:19PM | Share Article | Print Article

div.p: Please come out and join us as our students and staff showcase projects and activities that they have been working on and learning about this year. The night will begin with a short band concert from 6:00PM-6:20PM. Student projects and demonstrations will take place for the remainder of the night including:

· 5th—8th S.T.E.M. Projects (Science Technology Engineering & Math)
· 8th Grade Science Fair Projects
· 8th Grade Ofrendas (Spanish Class)
· 7th Grade History Fair Projects
· 6th Grade Ancient Egypt History/Stem Collaboration Project
· 6th Grade Academic Fair Projects
· 5th & 6th Grade Lamp Project
· 3rd-4th Sandwich Book Reports
· 1st-2nd Grade Familia Trees (Spanish Class)
· Kindergarten 100th Day Projects
· K-8 Art Work
· ...and various K-8 classroom projects
We are proud of our students and thankful for the commitment of excellence from our staff, board and community. We look forward to seeing you at our special event!

h2.a: Administrative Assistant at Dimmick School Traveling to Honduras

div.div: Wednesday, March 4, 2020 at 12:28PM | Share Article | Print Article

Carol Wineinger, Administrative Assistant at Dimmick School, is traveling to Honduras with her husband, Marty, to help at a Christian orphanage and school. The orphanage houses about 50 children and an additional 150 children come from surrounding community for the day school.

p.br: The Wineingers will be traveling with a group of 18 people through World Gospel Missions. While they are there they will be working on construction projects, including painting and installing plumbing. Marty will also be giving astronomy courses tailored to different age groups. For the courses he is bringing a computerized telescope and other presentation equipment. This will be a unique opportunity to teach science and mathematics to the children in a way that is both interesting and engaging. Other subjects being taught during the time are English, art, and crafts. In the future, the Wineingers hope to be more involved teaching vocational skills such as computers, woodworking, and 3D printing.

Also while there, Carol has planned a FaceTime hookup with the Spanish class at Dimmick School for a live cultural exchange between the two schools. Faculty at both schools are excited about this opportunity.

div.div: This outreach will be a great opportunity for the children in both schools, but particularly for the students in Honduras. The name of the school is Manuelito, and it is located near the city of Tegulcigalpa. With a population of 1.26 million, Tegulcigalpa is the largest city in Honduras, but it provides little employment opportunity for young people without strong occupational skills. Honduras is one of the poorest country in the western hemisphere, second only to Haiti, so education and vocational training are important to improve living conditions for both individuals and the community as a whole.

h2.a: 2020 Spaghetti Dinner Update

div.div: Tuesday, March 3, 2020 at 03:22PM | Share Article | Print Article

div.p: 2020 Spaghetti Dinner Update

Thank you to everyone for supporting our spaghetti dinner fundraiser! A special thank you to all of our volunteers who helped prepare for the dinner and volunteered the day of. We could not host our dinner without the support and hard work of the volunteers. Thank you to Mrs. Krolak and Mrs. Wineinger for helping to hand out and collect ticket packets. A very special thank you to Mr. Seghi who spends all day Friday, Saturday, and Sunday helping us prepare for and put on the dinner and does so much cleaning up after!!
We served 730 people and raised $10,800.
Winner of the 50/50 was Melinda Truckenbrod. The payout was $190.
Winner of the Pick 3 was Kate Barr - $500

h2.a: Information from the CDC Regarding the Coronavirus

div.div: Friday, February 28, 2020 at 12:48PM | Share Article | Print Article

div.p: Dear Parents and Guardians,

Below is a link from the CDC regarding the Coronavirus. Included in the link is information on how the virus spreads, prevention and treatment, symptoms, what to do if sick and frequently asked questions.

In addition, the District will continue to implement its diligent cleaning and sanitation practices and encourage students and staff to use universal precautions emphasizing frequent and thorough hand washing. We ask parents to stress those practices to their children at home as well.
As we receive updates from the CDC we will be sure to share them with you.

Mr. Ryan Linnig
Superintendent

h2.a: 3rd Grade Reward

div.div: Wednesday, February 26, 2020 at 12:04PM | Share Article | Print Article

div.p: The challenge was on and the third graders knew exactly what they wanted as their reward! They were determined to turn Mr. Linnig into a Green Bay Packers fan for the day! Every third grader had to read 700 minutes over a two month span. If as a class they read an EXTRA 1,000 minutes, then Mr. Linnig would be a Packer fan for the day. The third graders amazed themselves (and Mr. Linnig!) when they read 3,012 extra minutes!! Great job third graders! We are proud of your accomplishment!

div.p: We are planning a celebration in honor of Dr. Seuss’s birthday. We will be incorporating many Dr. Seuss books into our celebration, along with having Student Council members reading books to the students.
